page.title: 04Hatfield Broad Oak Church
page.content: St Mary's Church, or more fully, the parish church of St Mary the Virgin, once formed part of a Benedictine Priory and the present church building represents only half of the original monastic church. The tower, which is 81 feet (25m) high, is a notable local landmark. An interesting feature of the nave is the series of corbels at the tops of the columns supporting the roof. These are portraits of people such as King Richard II who were associated with the parish or with the 14th century rebuilding of the church. The chancel contains a fine stone effigy of Robert de Vere, 3rd Earl of Oxford, which originally stood before the high altar of the priory church. On the south side of the chancel is the library, built in 1708, which houses a fine and valuable collection of books.
